text: How many isotopes has hydrogen?
Which of the following electrons configurations correctly represents an inert element?
What type of reaction is represented by the following equation?\(\frac{2}{1}\)D\(\frac{3}{1}\)H → \(\frac{4}{4}\)He + \(\frac{1}{0}\)n + energy
Which of the following ions has the electron configuration 2,8,8?
explanation:
Chlorine(Cl) has configuration 2,8,7 but Chlorine ion (Cl-) has 18 electrons and configuration 2,8,8.
Here is the reason:
Chlorine has 17 electrons, and these are distributed in shells (or energy levels) as follows: 2 in the first shell, 8 in the second, and 7 in the third.This is represented as 2,8 7. Chlorine can gain one electron to achieve a stable electron configuration, resembling that of the noble gas Argon.
When chlorine gains an electron, its electron configuration becomes 2, 8, 8, making it a chloride ion (Cl⁻). The 2,8,8 configuration means the outermost shell is full with 8 electrons, which is the octet rule, making the ion stable.

On evaporation to dryness, 250 cm3 of saturated solution of salt X with relative molar mass 101 gave 50.5g of the. What is the soluility of the salt?
explanation:
50.5g 0f salt X is contained in 250cm3,
what mass of X is contained in 1000cm3
= (50.5 x 1000) ÷ 250 = 202g
no of moles of salt x = mass÷ molar mass
= 202÷ 101 = 2.0mol/dm3

text:
Consider the following reaction equation:
X(g) + Y(g) ⇌ XY(g); ∆H = + 220KJ mol-1 If the temperature of the system is increased, the
explanation: According to Le Chatelier's principle, in an endothermic reaction (whenever delta H = +), an increase in temperature will cause the equilibrium position to shift to the right, thereby leading to the formation of more of the product i.e The forward reaction will be favoured while a decrease in temperature will cause the equilibrium position to shift to the left. Which implies the backward reaction will be favoured. The reverse is the case in an exothermic reaction ( whenever delta H = - ). Therefore, the correct answer is option B.

text: When bromine is added to ethene at room temperature, the compound formed is
The compound that makes palm wine taste sour after exposure to the air for few days is
The reagent that can be used to distinguish ethene from ethyne is
explanation:
To distinguish between ethene and ethyne: i Add a few drops of ammonical copper(I) chloride to each of ethylene (ethene) and acetylene (ethyne). No change will be observed in the case of ethylene (ethene) but in the case of acetylene (ethyne), a red precipitate of copper acetylide is formed. similar result
ii) When ammoniacal Silver Nitrate (AgNO3) is added to Ethyne then it gives white precipitates. But when Ammoniacal silver nitrate is added to Ethene then no reaction occurs and no precipitates obtain.
